audioDescription: Since Mount Pisgah is at high elevation there is often fog. On a clear day one can see far across the mountains, covered in evergreen and deciduous trees. In spring the light greens of budding new growth will be visible alongside the dots of dark green spruce. In summer the view will be of rounded peaks of green while in fall the vibrant reds, oranges and yellows will be mixed in with the dark of the spruce. Mount Pisgah itself has a tall radio tower at the top, helping to identify it.

title: Mount Pisgah Picnic Area
listingDescription: Mount Pisgah Picnic Area provides a summer retreat from the heat just a 45-minute drive south from the Asheville area. At an elevation of about 5,000 feet, temperatures are typically 10 – 15 degrees cooler than low lying areas nearby. Whether driving the Blue Ridge Parkway or getting away for the day, enjoying a picnic lunch at this picnic area can round out a mountain pleasure trip.

images.altText: People eating at a picnic table under a large, mature oak tree across a grassy field.
images.title: Mount Pisgah Picnic Area
images.caption: Mount Pisgah Picnic Area

bodyText:
The Mount Pisgah Picnic Area is quietly tucked on a knoll across the Parkway from the Mount Pisgah trailhead parking lot and and just down the road from the Pisgah Inn. It offers day trippers the opportunity to stop and enjoy a break. It also affords cool temperatures in the heat of summer as it is at an elevation of almost 5,000 feet, where temperatures can be 10 – 15 degrees cooler than in nearby valleys.

The park-like picnic area is not visible from the parking lot. Use the paved walking path beside the gated driveway (the driveway does NOT lead to the picnic area) to climb up to the picnic area. A rocky trail can also be used to access the picnic area, it is located on the right-hand side of the parking lot near the grass. Mount Pisgah Picnic Area is located on a rolling hilltop. Mature oak trees surround a rambling grassy field. Rhododendrons are tucked beneath the massive oaks. All of this is combined to make for a serene and relaxing picnic setting.

This picnic area is open from late May until October. A variety of picnic tables are in full shade, partial shade, and in the grassy open area, and provide for the selection of a perfect lunch location. Folks from the area also bring their own blankets and spread out right on the grass. Grills are located throughout the picnic area to be shared by all.

Ample parking is available in the level, asphalt parking lot. Be aware that access on the paved trail from the parking lot is steep at a grade of approximately 15%. The picnic area has a short loop trail associated with the initial paved trail, continuing on a dirt road past the restroom building, turning off the dirt road into a rhododendron tunnel, then returning to the parking area. A trail at the north end of the picnic area parking lot connects to the Mount Pisgah Trail. A trail at the south end connects to the Mount Pisgah Campground.
audioDescription: This hilltop picnic area has an open sunny field with tables spaced along the edges. The woods around the edge of the open field have mature trees with rhododendrons in the understory. Picnic tables are nestled beneath in little shrubby alcoves. Grills, trash cans, and a comfort station are available during the season.

title: Mount Pisgah Trailhead
listingDescription: Mount Pisgah Trailhead, located in the Mount Pisgah parking area, provides access to scenic views, wildlife watching, and hiking. Hiking the Mount Pisgah Trail is one of the challenging and rewarding activities available on the southern end of the Blue Ridge Parkway.

images.altText: Large Mt. Pisgah information sign stands beside a gravel footpath leading into the woods.
images.title: Mount Pisgah Trailhead
images.caption: The journey begins!

bodyText:
Mount Pisgah is named after the biblical mountain from which Moses first saw the promised land. The first recorded use of the name appeared in this area in 1808. More than two hundred years later, people still flock here for the inspiring views.

The Mount Pisgah Trailhead is located at the far end of the Mount Pisgah parking area at Milepost 407.6. Turn off the Parkway and drive past the Buck Springs Gap Overlook to the end of the road. Nice views are available across rolling mountains from the sidewalk in this parking lot. If you want to know where the trail leads, look for the TV tower on the tallest mountaintop nearby. The local television station has its tower on top of Mount Pisgah. The Mountains-to-Sea Trail (including a portion called the Shut-In Trail) passes nearby here and there is a connector trail from here to the picnic area and campground as well.

It is a 1.6-mile hike to the summit of Mount Pisgah, with an ascent of 712 feet. The latter half of the moderate to strenuous hike is steep and rocky. Plant life is diverse along the initial portion of the trail. Birdsong is rich and musical in spring and early summer. The trail passes through a northern red oak forest with a thick shrub understory and ends at a deciduous heath bald at the summit. It offers a spectacular view, including the French Broad River Valley and Shining Rock Wilderness. On a clear day you can see the City of Asheville.
audioDescription: The Mount Pisgah Trailhead is located at the end of a level asphalt parking lot which is bounded on one side with a level asphalt sidewalk which requires one step up over a rock curb. There is a line of shrubbery running along the sidewalk and down a hillside toward to Parkway. Across the parking lot there is a small incline with trees and woods leading off onto a mountainside. A small gap is adjacent to the woods and allows for a beautiful view of a valley. Where the Mount Pisgah Trail heads into the forest, mature trees make a gap just wide enough for the trail to enter the woods. Beyond the tree line the trail disappears into shadow and foliage.

title: Mt. Lyn Lowry Overlook
listingDescription: Located along the southern end of the Blue Ridge Parkway, Mt. Lyn Lowry Overlook provides scenic views of Mt. Lyn Lowry, the Woodfin Cascades, and the 60-foot cross erected in Lyn Lowry’s honor. In 1962, this mountain was re-named for Lowry, a fifteen-year-old who died of leukemia.

images.altText: A gray overlook sign sits in front of green rounded mountains
images.title: Mt. Lyn Lowry
images.caption: View from Mt. Lyn Lowry Overlook

bodyText:
This overlook has plenty to offer. Not only can you take in a beautiful view of Mt. Lyn Lowry (elevation 6,240 feet), there is also a wide picnic area, gorgeous cascade, and significant history associated with the area.  

This mountain was renamed in 1965 in memory of Lyn Lowry, a 15-year-old victim of leukemia. Her parents, retired Army Lieutenant General Sumpter Lowry and Ivilyn Lowry, were determined to honor their daughter’s legacy at one of her favorite vacation spots. On the east side of the ridge, Lowry's parents installed a 60-foot-tall cross and a memorial plaque. On a clear day, the cross can be seen from Waynesville, Sylva, and other Western North Carolina towns as far as 30 miles away. The Reverend Billy Graham presided over the dedication ceremony.

Across the overlook, the Woodfin Cascades topples down the mountainside. It is best seen in the winter or early springtime when leaves are sparse. But a thin strip of water is visible throughout the summer, especially after a hard rain. There is no easy access to this waterfall, so the best view is from the overlook.
audioDescription: Paved pull-off with approximately a dozen parking spaces directly off the Blue Ridge Parkway. This overlook contains a picnic table set back in a grassy area. Mt. Lyn Lowry, a tall peak in the Plott Balsam Range, can be seen from the overlook, as well as Woodfin Cascades, a thin waterfall best spotted in the wintertime.

title: North Cove Overlook
listingDescription: The North Cove Overlook is a bucket list destination for Railroad enthusiasts. Watch trains climb out of the valley below and up the engineering marvel known as “The Loops” as they struggle to cross the Blue Ridge at McKinney Gap. This was the site of the original scenic mountain highway known as the Crest of the Blue Ridge Highway whose concept inspired the later creation of the Blue Ridge Parkway. It also provides views of Peppers Creek, North Cove and Dobson Knob.

images.altText: A heavily forested valley surrounded by mountain ridges sits beneath a clear, blue summer sky
images.title: North Cove Overlook
images.caption: North Cove Overlook

bodyText:
The North Cove Overlook is located at an elevation of 2,815 feet in McKinney Gap on the Blue Ridge Parkway. It provides long range views to the south and southeast of North Cove, Peppers Creek Valley, Dobson Knob, and distant views of Wolf Pen, Hickory Nut Mountain, Sugarloaf, Piney Mountain, Graveyard Mountain and more. Close up views of the Historic Orchard at Altapass face west from the overlook.

The overlook has two picnic tables and parking for 15 cars. A wayside exhibit tells the history of the original Crest of the Blue Ridge Highway. Joseph Hyde Pratt, a North Carolina State Geologist, first proposed the scenic highway in 1906. His proposal anticipated the growth of the automobile industry and the subsequent boom it would bring in tourists flocking to see the natural beauty of the Blue Ridge Mountains. Eight miles of the scenic highway were built from this location running north towards Linville Falls, but the outbreak of World War I brought the construction to an end. The idea of a scenic highway would be revived more than a decade later in the 1930s—becoming today’s Blue Ridge Parkway. 

The wayside has a historic photograph of a group of workmen and two teams of mules grading the roadbed for the Crest of the Blue Ridge Highway in 1913. It also has a map of the proposed route of the road beginning in Marion, Virginia running through Western North Carolina and ending at Tullulah Falls, Georgia.

Railroad enthusiasts prize the North Cove Overlook because it provides views of the trains ascending from the valley below, up the slopes of the Blue Ridge mountains on the railroad engineering marvel known as "The Loops."  Constructing a railroad with a sufficiently low grade to cross the steep slopes of the Blue Ridge Mountains was a daunting task. Construction began in 1905 and was completed in 1908. It is 13.5 miles long, contains 18 tunnels and many switchback curves that give “The Loops” its name. It required the labor of 4,000 workmen, most of whom were immigrants from Italy, Russia and Germany. Accidents and violence are believed to have cost more than 200 of these workers their lives.

Once completed the railroad forever changed the lives of the mountain families as timber and mining companies offering steady wages flocked to the area. Trains pass just below the Orchard at Altapass and disappear into a tunnel below McKinney Gap to emerge on the other side of the Blue Ridge. The Loops are best viewed after the leaves fall from the trees. 

The overlook also provides views to the west of the Historic Orchard at Altapass. The Orchard was created in 1908 by the Clinchfield Railroad and has been in operation for well over a century. It was considered to be an ideal location for an orchard because it could take advantage of the largely frost-free thermal layer found on the slopes of the Blue Ridge Mountains.  

McKinney Gap is named for Charles McKinney (1780-1852) who lived here with his very large family in the 1800s.
audioDescription: The North Cove Overlook is located on Parkway at an elevation of 2815 ft. It is a large semicircular overlook with enough space to accommodate 15 cars. There are two picnic table in its grassy median that are shaded by a white pine and a mix of hardwoods. There is a trash can and a wayside exhibit about the “First Mountain Parkway.” Southeast lies the Peppers Creek Valley which connects to North Cove. To the south, forested mountain ridges dominate. To the West apple trees cover the hillside at the Historic Orchard at Altapass. Looping up the mountain slopes ringing the Peppers Creek Valley is the cut in the treeline marking the route of the railway.

quickFacts.value: Site of the Crest of the Blue Ridge Highway, Scenic Overlook that provides views of North Cove and the Historic Orchard at Altapass
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Onion Mountain Overlook
listingDescription: Onion Mountain Overlook is a lovely stop to to snap a quick pic of a great view, stretch your legs, share a picnic meal, and enjoy the forested mountains of the Blue Ridge.

images.altText: Golden fall colors cloak mountainsides and fill a valley below
images.title: Onion Mountain Overlook
images.caption: Onion Mountain Overlook

bodyText:
One of the original goals of the parkway's designers was to provide visitors with a chance to “drive a while, stop a while.” With its good view, short leg stretcher trail, and opportunity for picnicking, Onion Mountain Overlook fits the bill. 

Onion Mountain Overlook (3,145 feet) provides views southeast over Suck Mountain and the piedmont 2,000 feet below. The overlook is nestled into the forest with a nice view from the picnic table, and offers a short 0.2 mile loop trail on the southern end of the overlook. 

Seasonal highlights include blooming rhododendrons in late spring, bird watching with migrating warblers spring and fall migrating raptors, and excellent opportunities to take in the fall colors across the expansive views in October.
audioDescription: Onion Mountain Overlook is a paved parking area directly adjacent to the parkway road. It is surrounded by forest except for a large maintained opening to the east-southeast. The mowed meadow slopes steeply away from the overlook into the dense deciduous forest below. A stone picnic table offers a view over the low lying Suck Mountain and green valley of the piedmont 2,000 feet below. The forest surrounds the overlook on three sides with oaks, hickories, and rhododendron shrubs.

title: Peaks of Otter Picnic Area
listingDescription: The Peaks of Otter has been a favorite stop for travelers for 8,000 years on their journeys across the mountains. Most have stopped along the banks of Stony Creek to refresh themselves with spring water, replenish their strength with a good meal, and rest in the cool shade of the forest. The Peaks of Otter picnic area offers creekside tables, charcoal grills, restrooms, and allows you the chance to become part of this millennia old traveler’s tradition.

images.altText: A wooden bridge leads over a small creek to a picnic table in the shade of tall trees.
images.title: Peaks of Otter Picnic Area
images.caption: Find a shady spot to rest along Little Stony Creek

bodyText:
The Peaks of Otter Picnic Area offers 58 picnic tables and grills scattered along a half mile of Little Stony Creek. The sites offer a wide range of scenery from cozy creekside tables nestled between spicebushes to a large group area with an open meadow great for games and play.

Many of the sites have a charcoal grill for you to prepare favorite foods over open flames. There are two comfort stations with cold potable water and flushing toilets, and you can dispose of trash in the on-site dumpsters. All tables and sites are available on a first come, first served basis. The Peaks of Otter Picnic Area is an open-air area with no covered tables or seating during inclement weather. The picnic area is open seasonally from May to November. Roadside tables are available throughout the year along the Parkway motor road.
audioDescription: The Peaks of Otter Picnic Area is located along both sides of Little Stony Creek in the narrow valley below highway 43. It is a half mile gently sloping valley bottom of varied habitats including mowed field, shrubby shaded forest, and wetlands. The stone tables are weathered and covered with moss and lichen. The creek is shallow and varies between 3 to 8 feet across in places. The paved access road runs along the north side of the picnic area offering sporadic parking slips and access to both of the gray colored two room comfort stations.

quickFacts.value: Located along a route between the piedmont and Great Valley of Virginia, the ‘Big Spring’ in the picnic area has refreshed travelers for some 8,000 years and the valley forest has shaded many a replenishing meal along Stony Creek.
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Pink Beds Overlook
listingDescription: The Pink Beds Overlook near Mount Pisgah has outstanding views into the valley below named for its colorful seasonal blooms.

images.altText: Trees changing colors with mountains in the background
images.title: Pink Beds in Autumn
images.caption: Pink Beds in Autumn

bodyText:
Named after the wide variety of pink flowers found by the settlers coming into the area, Pink Beds Overlook offers an expansive view into the large valley below of the small name.

Visitors arriving in the late spring and early summer have the chance to experience the sight of these flowers in bloom for themselves, namely the mountain laurel and rhododendron which grow prolifically in the region. Those wishing to hike in this valley can find trail access in the Pisgah National Forest.
audioDescription: This overlook is a paved, pull-through overlook with a grassy median. A rock curbing steps up to a level sidewall offering an eastern view into the Pisgah National Forest.

title: Plott Balsam Overlook
listingDescription: Located near the Southern end of the Blue Ridge Parkway, Plott Balsam Overlook offers scenic views of the extensive Plott Balsam Range. This area was named for Henry Plott, a German immigrant’s son who bred the famous Plott Bear Hounds, which are prized for their stamina and alertness.

images.altText: Green layered mountains bathed in sunlight and topped with white clouds
images.title: View from Plott Balsam Overlook
images.caption: View from Plott Balsam Overlook

bodyText:
The Blue Ridge Parkway travels the spine of some of the highest mountains in the Plott Balsam Range, which were named for the Plott family. Plott Balsam Overlook has an informational sign that explores some of this family history, including the creation of their famed hunting dogs, the Plott Bear Hounds. In 1989, the North Carolina General Assembly honored the Plott Hound with the designation of official State Dog.

At 5,020 feet, Plott Balsam Overlook offers sweeping views of this protected landscape, which includes a variety of habitats like Appalachian spruce-fir forests, northern hardwood forests, rock outcroppings, and high-elevation bogs.

The extensive Plott Balsam Range stretches southwest from the Tuckasegee River Valley in Sylva, NC to Maggie Valley, NC in the northeast. This range is often overlooked due to being flanked by the taller Great Smoky Mountains to the north and the Great Balsams to the south. But seasoned Parkway visitors know that some of the best views can be seen from the Plott Balsams. Waterrock Knob (6,292 feet) is the highest peak in the Plott Balsam Range, while Waterrock Knob Visitor Center, at 5,820 feet, is the highest-elevation center along the Parkway.
audioDescription: Wide, U-shaped, paved pull-off with ample parking spaces directly off the Blue Ridge Parkway. This overlook contains an informational exhibit about Henry Plott and his famous hunting dogs. The Plott Balsams, a large mountain range, can be seen from the overlook.

title: Polly Wood's Ordinary
listingDescription: Easy to overlook, Polly Wood’s Ordinary provides a key link in the evolution of travel accommodations in Virginia, especially at the Peaks of Otter. The ordinary is a step up from sleeping in tent and yet is vastly different from what most travelers today expect from a night in a hotel/lodge.
bodyText:
Polly Wood’s Ordinary served travelers on the Buchanan to Liberty Turnpike and visitors to the Peaks of Otter from the early 1830s to the late 1850s. It is a good example of the simple, rather rough and ready, accommodation, which was characteristic of the period. The ordinary is a reminder that the Peaks of Otter settlement was not isolated, but has been visited by travelers throughout its history.

Widow Polly Wood opened her home to passing travelers as a place to get the “ordinary” things needed for life during their trips. The Ordinary is credited as the first public place of accommodation Peaks of Otter area, operated by Polly and her family along the Buchanan to Liberty (now Bedford) turnpike. It was a place for weary travelers to shelter for the night and place to get a meal and rest livestock.

In 1952, Regional Historian Holland wrote that the Ordinary, “is the most interesting and significant structure on the Blue Ridge Parkway.” During the construction of Abbott Lake in 1964, the National Park Service reassembled the Ordinary a few hundred yards to the east of its original site, noted as one of the more controversial landscape decisions along the Blue Ridge Parkway. Like other structures along the Parkway, the Ordinary has become a picturesque feature in a carefully composed scene.
audioDescription: A two-story log cabin measuring 23’9” by 19’6” with thick layers of white cement chinking between the logs and a peaked, wood shingle roof. There are two downstairs rooms of unequal size divided by a partition. A ladder in the smaller room leads to two attic rooms. There are doors in the middle of the front and rear elevation, and a single window at the front. The joists of the attic floor are visible resting on the second log above the doors. There is an external fieldstone chimney on the east side, with two small windows on each side to light the attic. The gable roof is covered by wood shakes. The structure is situated across a grassy field from the lake, right at the edge of a deciduous forest.

quickFacts.value: It is a good example of the simple, rather rough and ready, accommodation, which was characteristic of the mid 19th century.
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Price Lake Picnic Area TRACK Trail for Kids
listingDescription: Enjoy a short, kid-friendly nature hike though the woods and along a creek. This 0.7-mile walk (1.4 miles round-trip) features wayside signs about beavers and their activity in the area.

images.altText: A woman and child wearing backpacks hike on a path through the forest
images.title: Hiking With Child
images.caption: Take your kids hiking!

bodyText:
The Julian Price Memorial Park Picnic Area TRACK Trail uses a portion of the Boone Fork Trail beginning at the bridge by the picnic area restroom. The TRACK Trail portion of the Boone Fork Trail is a kid-friendly 0.7-mile walk (1.4 miles round-trip) and concludes at a rock overhang. At the rock overhang, turn around and return to the picnic area. The entire Boone Fork Trail is a 5-mile loop and includes several strenuous sections that may not be suitable for young children.

The hike begins in an open field area scattered with picnic tables, trees, and rhododendron. Behind a restroom building, a small wooden foot bridge crosses a gentle creek and a dirt path winds around through the open field and parallel with the creek. Vegetation continues to thicken and in many places the creek has eroded its sides very near the trail. At the conclusion of the Track Trail section, a huge boulder juts out providing a roof type structure over the trail.

For additional information about the Kids In Parks TRACK Trail program and to download activity brochures for Price Park, visit kidsinparks.com. Print the TRACK Trail Adventure Scavenger Hunt and Birds of the Blue Ridge Mountains activity brochures to use along the trail.

quickFacts.value: Julian Price Memorial Park Picnic Area at Parkway Milepost 296.4
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: A family-friendly trail especially for kids
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Price Lake TRACK Trail for Kids
listingDescription: There are two types of TRACK Trails at Price Lake – hiking and paddling. Enjoy a boating trip around a 47-acre mountain lake or take a stroll along the water's edge. Print the TRACK trail adventure Hiking and Boating Scavenger Hunt activity brochures to use during your visit.

images.altText: Two kayakers paddle on a calm lake, surrounded by a forest
images.title: Kayakers on Price Lake
images.caption: One of the Price Lake TRACK Trails is a paddling trail

bodyText:
There are two types of TRACK Trails at Price Lake—hiking and paddling. Enjoy a boating trip around a 47-acre mountain lake or take a stroll along the water's edge.

The hiking TRACK Trail is located on a portion of the Price Lake Trail beginning at the boat rental dock and ending at the beaver dam overlook. The hiking TRACK Trail is a 1-mile walk (2 miles round-trip). The entire Price Lake Trail is a 2.7-mile loop.

The paddling TRACK Trail on Price Lake is 2-miles round-trip if you follow the perimeter of the 47-acre lake. Canoes, kayaks and paddleboards can be rented seasonally for use on Price Lake; however, motorized boats and swimming are not allowed. You may also bring your own watercraft. For your safety, you are required to wear a flotation device.

Whether hiking or boating, Julian Price Lake is a beautiful spot. The hiking trail is a hard-packed dirt trail in most areas surrounded by rhododendron. The trail weaves in and out along the shore of the lake providing several access points to the clear sparkling water. Wooden boardwalks and foot bridges help with areas where the path traverses areas of beaver activity. Beaver gnawed tree stumps are commonly spotted along the trail, along with wood ducks floating on the lake.

By water, boaters can circle the 47-acre lake on gentle rocking waters sliding up into coves and exploring streams that feed the lake with cold water. The openness of the lake is a bright sparkling landscape on a sunny day.

quickFacts.value: Julian Price Memorial Park at Milepost 297
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: Hiking trail and paddling trail designed especially for kids
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Puckett Cabin
listingDescription: Puckett Cabin is a historic site that preserves the memory of “Aunt” Orlean Hawks Puckett, an Appalachian midwife who successfully delivered 1,000 babies during her career.

images.altText: A log cabin and small, log spring house sit on a grassy yard, surrounded by log fences
images.title: Puckett Cabin
images.caption: Puckett Cabin

bodyText:
Born around 1837, “Aunt Orlean” Puckett is a local legend. She lived here with her husband, John. Aunt Orlean was revered as a midwife who successfully delivered more than 1,000 babies. 

Orlean had 24 children of her own, but tragically, each one died in infancy. Many people speculate that this is why she worked so tirelessly to aid other mothers. “Aunt” Orlean Hawks Puckett died in 1939 at the age of 94 or 102, no one is quite sure which! (Not only is her age unknown, the spelling of her name varies based on the historical source.)

An informational wayside on the site explains, "Born in 1837, “Aunt” Orelena Hawks Puckett lived here during the latter of her 102 years. She was often heard to say, “The Forest was green when I was a-born and I’m green yet.” A bride at 16, Mrs. Puckett and her husband first farmed below nearby Groundhog Mountain.

Mrs. Puckett was past age 50 when she began a long career of midwifery. She assisted at the births of more than 1,000 babies, delivering the last in 1939, the year she died. It has been said she never lost a child or mother through her own fault. Ironically, none of Mrs. Puckett’s own 24 children lived beyond infancy.

Regardless of weather, “Aunt” Orelena went wherever and whenever called. Sometimes on horseback, often walking, the midwife brought assurance and kindness to all she visited. When she began her practice around 1890 her fee was one dollar, and “when time was good,” six dollars. Often receiving food or other goods in lieu of money, she generously shared all she had with neighbors or those in need. Today, Orelena Puckett is remembered in this area for her witty, cheerful personality, as well as for her unselfish and skillful practice as a midwife.”

Orlean and John Puckett lived in a larger house that was located in what is now the garden plot on this site. The cabin here currently was moved to the property for one of John’s sisters to live in. It is preserved by the National Park Service to keep the memory of Orlean alive.
audioDescription: A small, paved parking area sits in front of a small farm site, which includes a 16’ by 16’ cabin on the left, a small, log chicken house further back to the right, and various types of log fencing encloses both structures. A paved walkway leads visitors from the parking area to these historic structures. The log home has a main floor and loft, and was constructed with different types of logs; chestnut, pine, poplar, and oak. The house has wood shake roof, chimney and several small windows. An interpretive wayside near the parking area tells the story of Aunt Orlean’s life.

quickFacts.value: Orlean Puckett was a local midwife who successfully delivered 1,000 babies
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Rattlesnake Lodge Trailhead
listingDescription: The Rattlesnake Lodge Trailhead is the jumping off point for your adventure into the past. Enjoy a quiet hike through a lush forest as you steadily climb to the historic site of the Ambler family’s early 1900s summer retreat.

images.altText: Dirt parking areas on both sides of the Parkway with Tanbark Ridge Tunnel in the background
images.title: Rattlesnake Lodge Trailhead
images.caption: Rattlesnake Lodge Trailhead parking. Trail heads off to the left.

bodyText:
A hike to Rattlesnake Lodge is a fascinating trip back in time. The pleasant wooded hike just north of Asheville brings you to the remains of the summer retreat of Dr. Chase Ambler. The Ambler family enjoyed the lodge and surrounding property in the early 1900’s and gave it a most unusual name.

Rattlesnake Lodge was aptly named as 41 rattlesnakes were said to have been killed in the first three years the Amblers were there. The snake skins were hung on the living room ceiling. Certainly an interesting decorating choice! (Please note that it is against federal law to disturb or kill snakes in the area now.)

Rattlesnake Lodge can be the perfect hike when you're in the Asheville area. It’s great if you’re looking for a shorter hike or if your time is limited. It is also a less traveled trail than many others in the area, so give it a try if you crave a less crowded, quieter experience.

The trailhead for the Rattlesnake Lodge Trail is located at Milepost 374.4 on the Blue Ridge Parkway. On the south end of the Tanbark Ridge Tunnel there are dirt pull-offs on both sides of the road that serve as parking for the trailhead. The trail begins on the west side of the road next to a small cascading creek. The trail quickly splits and both sides climb steadily for approximately 0.5 miles to the historic Rattlesnake Lodge site.

Pets are allowed but must be on a leash no longer than 6 feet in length.
audioDescription: Large dirt and gravel pull offs on both sides of the Blue Ridge Parkway just south of the Tanbark Ridge Tunnel. Serves as the parking area for the Rattlesnake Lodge Trail. Mid-elevation deciduous forest surrounds the area. To the west, the slope rises steadily up towards the top of the ridge. To the east, the slope drops steadily into the valley below. A small creek flows over a rock face adjacent to the trailhead.

quickFacts.value: Milepost 374.4, approximately 15 minutes north of Asheville
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: Trailhead for the Rattlesnake Lodge Trail
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Richland Balsam Overlook
listingDescription: A must-have photo of your Blue Ridge Parkway visit is from Richland Balsam Overlook. It's the highest point on the Parkway and has an iconic sign for you to pose in front of.

images.altText: Gray wooden sign framed by stone designating the highest point on the Parkway
images.title: Richland Balsam
images.caption: Richland Balsam

bodyText:
Take in the expansive views of the Nantahala National Forest from the highest point on the Parkway at Richland Balsam Overlook.

Sitting at 6,053 feet above sea level, Richland Balsam is the highest point along the Blue Ridge Parkway motor road. Named for the red spruce and Fraser fir trees found here, known as the “he-balsam” and “she-balsam” respectively, this area features a forest type that resembles a Canadian wilderness. Since the late 1970s the forest has been affected by the balsam woolly adelgid, an invasive pest that has been killing Fraser fir trees.
audioDescription: This overlook is an asphalt, pull-through overlook with a grassy median. The median features a large sign denoting this location as highest point on the Parkway. A rock curbing steps up to a level sidewalk featuring various signs providing information about the area. From the curb the mountain begins a slope down into the Nantahala National Forest. This overlook offers a largely uninterrupted southwestern view into the forest.

title: Roanoke Mountain Picnic Area
listingDescription: Pick a shady table to enjoy a picnic or tap your toes to blue grass music at a concert. Roanoke Mountain is a former campground turned picnic area along the Mill Mountain Parkway.

images.altText: A concrete picnic table sitting in a forest in early winter, surrounded by bare trees.
images.title: Roanoke Mountain Picnic Area
images.caption: Roanoke Mountain Picnic Area

bodyText:
Roanoke Mountain day use area is slightly off the beaten path. Originally opened as a campground in 1966, it is located on the Mill Mountain Parkway, a 2.5-mile road connecting the Blue Ridge Parkway with Roanoke City’s Mill Mountain Park. The campground was repurposed and reopened as a day use area in 2014. 

One of the nicest things about this site is that most tables have their own parking space and are a short distance from the car. Tables that do not have individual parking have spaces nearby. Additionally, there are three handicap sites with a paved path leading up to the table. These are on the back half of the main picnic loop. 

Each site has a grilling surface in the fire ring. There are no designated group picnicking sites. Picnic sites are on a first come first serve basis. The area is typically open from late May to late October. Never leave food out in the open or unattended.

One of the biggest draws to this site is the weekend concert series held in the summer and autumn. These free concerts feature old time string bands, ballad singers, and bluegrass musicians. Bring chairs or blankets, as well as snacks and non-alcololic beverages. As a National Park site, alcohol is prohibited. Concerts take place outside and may be canceled in the event of inclement weather. 

Chestnut Ridge Trail, a moderate 5-mile loop, goes around the picnic area. A parking area for the trail is located on the left about 700 feet before you turn into the picnic area. There are several smaller paths in the picnic area that also  connect to the trail.
audioDescription: The picnic area is located on Mill Mountain Spur approximately a mile from the parkway. This area is mostly wooded and hilly. Just after passing the entrance gate there is a dumpster. To right is an old ranger check-in station. The building is about 10 feet by 6 feet. Approximately150 feet past the entrance gates there is a side road to the left that turns into a one-way loop leading to picnic sites. This area is not as well maintained as the main loop. Two hundred feet after this turn, the road becomes the main loop. The main loop is about 0.5-mile-long and has parking spaces on both the left and right. Near the beginning of the main loop, there is a small stage about 50 feet from the road in a clearing. The stage is 3-sided and is about 15 feet across. Up a hill to the right of the stage is a comfort station. The loop road continues going slightly uphill, providing more picnic tables. Some are farther in the woods and many have stairs leading up and down to them. About halfway around the main loop there is an access point to the Chestnut Ridge Trail and another comfort station to the right. Coming back down around towards the front of the picnic area, there is an additional access point to the first comfort station. At the road fork, turning left will circle back through the main loop, while turning right will take you to the other loop and exit. This second loop goes uphill about 0.2 mile before reaching tables. Along this road the Chestnut Ridge Trail crosses the road. This section of the picnic area is slightly more overgrown and access to the tables here is limited.

quickFacts.value: Just off the parkway on on the Mill Mountain Parkway in Roanoke
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: Picnic Area with old time and bluegrass music concerts on weekends in summer and fall
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Roanoke River Overlook
listingDescription: Overlook by the Roanoke River Bridge. View the Niagara power plant, a small hydroelectric dam and producer of electricity for the city of Roanoke. Also, access the Roanoke River Trail dropping down to a pedestrian river access for fishing.

images.altText: A sign reading Roanoke River Overlook, elevation 985 feet in front of a view of rolling mountains.
images.title: Roanoke River Overlook
images.caption: Park the car and stretch your legs while enjoying the view or walk the short trail to the river.

bodyText:
Stanley Abbot, the original Landscape Architect of the parkway chose to highlight water features along the route. As a result, we have the Roanoke River Overlook here at MP114. The river itself begins in Montgomery County, Virginia and passes through Roanoke on its way to empty into the Albemarle Sound in North Carolina.

At only 985’ of elevation, this is one of the lowest overlooks along the parkway, but it still offers an expansive view of the river and the Niagara Dam, sitting a little over 100’ below. Constructed in 1906, it continues to supply power to the city of Roanoke. Behind the plant is a portion of the Norfolk Southern Railway.  

This overlook is the starting point for the Roanoke River Trail, an easy 0.35 mile hike that goes down the cliff and gives other views of the river and plant. About halfway down, the trail splits into the Fisherman’s Trail, which goes to the river, or makes a loop, passing under the bridge to a smaller pedestrian overlook. Fishing is allowed with a valid license. Due to the strong current, swimming is not recommended at this site.

There are approximately 35 painted parking spaces at this site and some benches lining the area.
audioDescription: This parking lot lies just to the south of the 1000' Roanoke River Bridge. The surrounding area on both sides is wooded. The vista at this overlook is approximately 140’ across. To the far left side there is a large tree circled by a wooden bench. In front of the parking lot there is a paved walkway. In the center of this, there is a gravel path leading to a sign that reads the following, “Roanoke River Overlook / Elev. 985.” To the right of the sign is a bench and behind the sign is a fence along the length of the overlook. The area is wooded, and the land drops off behind the fence. The dam is about one-quarter of a mile in the distance. It is 52’ tall and 452’ wide. The reservoir is to the left of the dam and is the farthest point of the water visible. The water flows over the dam, dropping a significant amount before flowing past the plant, a stone structure on the opposite side of the river, and then to the nearby bridge. The land around the water is mostly wooded and hilly. On the opposite side of the river, there is also a railroad that follows the curve of the water. To the left side of the overlook, about 12’ past the tree with the bench, the Roanoke River Trail begins. A sign at the start of the trail reads the following; “Roanoke River Trail/ 20 minute walk along rocky cliffs above river gorge. Please stay on established trail. It is dangerous to climb on rocks. / Pedestrian overlook 1000 ft.”

title: Rocky Knob Picnic Area
listingDescription: One of the five original recreation areas for the Blue Ridge Parkway, containing picnic area, campground, trails, and overlooks. Individual mountain rising within the plateau region of the Parkway looking towards other mountains, and into gorge 2000’ below.

images.altText: a picnic table rests on a slope below tall hardwood trees
images.title: Rocky Knob Picnic Area
images.caption: The interesting topography of the Rocky Knob Picnic Area will delight while you rest.

bodyText:
Serving as one of the most frequented locations along the southern Virginia section of the Blue Ridge Parkway, the Rocky Knob Recreation Area at MP 169 contains a picnic area, campground, several nearby overlooks as well as trails that visitors may enjoy.

Built in 1937, the picnic area is one of the earliest projects completed on the parkway. Rocky Knob is so named from the rock that emerges above the surrounding plateau along with the rocky outcroppings found throughout the site. Views from this area include Buffalo Mountain and Rock Castle Gorge, which descends 2000’ down the mountain. Until 1962 the campground and picnic area were together, however due to increasing usage the campground was relocated to its current location 2 miles up the road its footprint converted into additional day use spots.

Due to the topography here, many of the picnic sites sit on a slope and may require a walk up or down the hill. The picnic area includes 72 tables and grills, several water fountains, two comfort stations, and a pavilion. Additionally, there are group picnic areas by the open field. Picnic sites are on a first come first serve basis. The area is typically open from late May to late October. Thank you for not leaving food unattended and for using the dumpsters provided.

Surrounding the picnic area is a 1.0 mile easy loop trail that can be accessed at several different points on site.
audioDescription: On the road into the picnic area, you will pass the Rocky Knob Visitor Center and additional parking for the Picnic Loop and Black Ridge trails. The picnic area is mostly wooded with large oaks, ashes, hickories, hemlocks, and magnolias. Dotted throughout the woods and picnic area are rock outcroppings. The land is sloped, left to the road goes downhill. At the first fork, a left will take you to a large parking area in front of a field and a picnic pavilion. Right at the fork and the road will then split again into two oval loops. At this divergence there is a comfort station. The smaller of the loops is the road to the right and will circle to the litter drop-off as well as additional picnic sites before exiting. Along this road there is a guard rail to the right and one of the stone retaining walls built during construction of this site. The larger loop road holds more picnic spots and the more prominent rock outcroppings. About one third of the way around there is a second comfort station and a drinking fountain. The last section features a stone tree well, a circular bed of rocks constructed around a tree. The second, larger loop, merges again with the first one at the litter drop-off. Past this, there is a red oak tree to the right of the car. forks one more time; going left, you will reenter the picnic loop, going right will direct you back towards the parkway.

quickFacts.value: One of the five original recreation areas for the Blue Ridge Parkway, containing picnic area, campground, trails, and overlooks
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Second Falls
listingDescription: Second Falls is one of two waterfalls that you can hike to at Graveyard Fields. This short, relatively easy hike makes it a popular destination in the summer as visitors flock to this high elevation mountain stream.

images.altText: Water flows over tiered rocks into a large pool at the bottom of the waterfall
images.title: Graveyard Fields
images.caption: Second Falls at Graveyard Fields

bodyText:
Be cautious while enjoying waterfalls around the Parkway. Do not climb on rocks near waterfalls and use extreme caution when walking along riverbanks. These rocks are slippery from mist and algae. The top of any waterfall is dangerous—never play in the stream above a waterfall.

Hike into a mile-high valley featuring spectacular waterfalls surrounded by rolling ridges. The Graveyard Fields Loop Trail is a very popular and reasonable hiking distance for families, including children, and includes waterfalls. The 1.3-mile loop trail is rated as easy overall, however the spur trails to the waterfalls are moderately steep. Trail access is from the Graveyard Fields Overlook at Milepost 418.8 of the Blue Ridge Parkway, but the area is managed by Pisgah National Forest. Finding a parking spot might require the willingness to park a significant distance away and walk on the road to the overlook. Signs on the roadsides clearly mark where motorists can and cannot park. Cars attempting to park in restricted areas have rolled over the edge down a steep embankment! If the parking lot is full, visit one of the other hiking areas available along the Blue Ridge Parkway.

The two waterfalls in the Graveyard Fields area are accessible from the trailhead near the vault toilets in the overlook. A trail map is available in the overlook parking lot. Familiarize yourself with the general loop trail prior to hiking. Taking a photo of the trail map is recommended. “Social trails” (or illegal trails) have been created over the years, which can make navigating confusing. Please do not compound this problem by going off the established trails. 

Second (or Lower) Falls is only 1/3 of a mile from the trailhead. Follow the trail down to the Yellowstone Prong, the stream that feed both waterfalls. After crossing the stream, take a right on the spur trail that follows the stream as it flows down to the waterfall. A series of stair steps will take you to the base of the waterfall for safe viewing, photography, and cooling off in the mist of the falls. Return to the loop trail the same way you came.

To reach the Upper Falls, continue on the loop trail through the beautiful open meadow. Look for a spur trail to the right after about a half a mile of hiking. It is before you recross the Yellowstone Prong. This 0.8-mile spur trail to the Upper Falls crosses small creeks and is rocky towards the end. The Upper Falls is divided into two sections, each accessible by a short side trail. At the lower section, the river flows over an angled rock outcrop resembling a chute before pooling above several large boulders. The upper section is a classic tall waterfall where the water falls over a high cliff and flows over a rock face.

To return to your car, follow the Upper Falls Spur Trail back to the Graveyard Fields Loop Trail. Turn right on the loop trail where it will cross the Yellowstone Prong and ascend through a rhododendron thicket back to the other end of the parking lot.

Be aware that camping is not allowed in the Graveyard Fields area. During the season, the nearest National Park Service campground is located at Mount Pisgah. In the winter, the Blue Ridge Parkway may be closed in this area due to ice and snow.
audioDescription: A multi-level cascade drops over a series of ledges, with some free-falling sections, into a deep, clear pool at the base. The smooth rock is layered with colorful bands, and the area around the falls are covered with rhododendron, mountain laurel, and deciduous trees like maple.

title: Sharp Top
listingDescription: For hundreds of years, Sharp Top Mountain has been a favorite destination for travelers to the Blue Ridge Mountains. The summit towers over the Peaks of Otter and offers expansive views of the valley below, the surrounding mountains, and the piedmont to the east. Mountains are visible far in the distance some 30 miles or more on most days.

images.altText: Two hikes stand among large boulders on a high peak, with a small lake and logde in the valley below
images.title: Sharp Top
images.caption: The view from Sharp Top

bodyText:
One of the most popular trails is all of Virginia is the strenuous climb up to the rocky summit of Sharp Top Mountain (3,875 feet), This peak has attracted hikers for hundreds, if not thousands, of years. This 1.5 mile trail ascends 1,300 vertical feet through the forests on Sharp Top Mountain to spectacular 360° views of the Peaks of Otter and surrounding landscape.

For a less crowded experience, consider relaxing at the Buzzard’s Roost spur rather than hiking all the way up to the summit. Be sure to enjoy the plants and animals that live along this trail and don’t be surprised to run into many of them on your trip.

Hike Notes:

  • Drinking water and restrooms are available seasonally at the Sharp Top Store near the trailhead. Be sure to carry enough snacks and water with you for this hike.
  • Practice Leave No Trace when visiting. Please pack out all trash and leave only footprints behind.
  • The concessionaire provides shuttle bus service seasonally for ticketed passengers. The shuttle drops hikers within 0.25 miles of the summit, for a shorter, though still strenuous climb up the stairs to the top.
  • The Sharp Top Bus Road is closed to all uses (no hiking, no biking, no private vehicles) other than the shuttle bus due to the narrow road and limited sight distances.

quickFacts.value: Near Bedford, Virginia at Parkway Milepost 86
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Sims Pond
listingDescription: Sims Pond is a small, man-made pond formed by and earth and stone dam and fed by Sims Creek. It's a picturesque spot that serves as the trail head for the Green Knob Trail.

images.altText: A green forest surrounds a quiet pond, while pink rhododendrons bloom in the foreground.
images.title: Sims Pond
images.caption: Sims Pond

bodyText: Sims Pond is a small, man-made pond formed by and earth and stone dam and fed by Sims Creek. It was originally constructed as one of a series of ponds to be used for raising rainbow trout for Price Lake, but is no longer used for this purpose. It's a picturesque spot that serves as the trail head for the Green Knob Trail. The pond is located a short walk from the parking area.
audioDescription: An asphalt parking area with an asphalt sidewalk and stone curbs. The walk is lined with a stacked rail fence to protect visitors from a 12 ft. drop. On the left end of the parking area is the top of a sloping path down to the pond. The pond is rectangular in shape, with far sides covered in rhododendrons and hardwoods. The near side is stone lined. The right side is a stone and earth dam with a trail crossing the top. A sluice for overflow cuts across the beginning of the trail and is crossed by an iron and concrete bridge.

quickFacts.value: Trout pond for original plan of Price Lake.
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Sliding Rock
listingDescription: This popular swimming hole is a short drive off the Blue Ridge Parkway on US 276 South. It provides is a cool, refreshing oasis from the hot summer sun.

images.altText: Rock face with water cascading into pool below
images.title: Sliding Rock
images.caption: Sliding Rock

bodyText:
Be cautious while enjoying waterfalls around the Parkway. Do not climb on rocks near waterfalls and use extreme caution when walking along riverbanks. These rocks are slippery from mist and algae. The top of any waterfall is dangerous—never play in the stream above a waterfall.

Sliding Rock is 7 miles off the Blue Ridge Parkway on US 276 South in the Pisgah National Forest. Although not technically a waterfall, this natural rock water slide is a place you can slide down 60 feet and plunge into a deep water pool. Check with Pisgah National Forest for current hours and fees.

From the parking lot, it is a short, easy walk down a paved walkway to a wooden observation platform. Here you can view the rock water slide and 8-foot deep plunge pool. If you wish to slide, continue down the path to the water's edge and carefully walk up the left side of the slide. Slide from the middle of the cascading water into the refreshing cool water pool below. Be patient, Sliding Rock can be very busy and crowded in the summer. During peak times, lifeguards are on duty to assist.
audioDescription: Approximately 60-foot long and 30-foot wide rock face with water cascading over the surface to create a natural rock slide. There is a large, deep pool of water at the base of the rock slide. Two metal handrails line the left side of the rock face. Mixed deciduous forest surrounds the area.

quickFacts.value: Pisgah National Forest, 7 miles from the Parkway at MP 411
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Smart View Overlook
listingDescription: Overlook along the Smart View Recreation Area that shows a view between two nearby converging hills into the Pigg River Valley below.

images.altText: Wooden sign, Smart View Overlook, 2564, then lush green field of small shrubs in front of forest.
images.title: Smart View Overlook Sign
images.caption: The Smart View Overlook offers an unique view compared to other parkway stops.

bodyText:
The view from this overlook is not the broad, sweeping expanse offered by most stops along the parkway. Instead, your gaze is directed to the convergence of two sloping hills creating a gunsight view of the land below. This area was named for the “right smart views” that look out from the crest of the Blue Ridge, off the escarpment into the Pigg River valley below. 

The view from this overlook has changed over time. Originally, much of the land along the parkway was cleared for farming and offered unobstructed views for miles. However, as trees grew in, some of the views have changed. Today Smart View Overlook shows a forested area over the lowland hills.

The Smart View Trail, an easy to moderate 2.6-mile loop, can be reached from the overlook and passes by the Trail Family Cabin and the Smart View Picnic Area. There is a designated parking area for this trail at the entrance to the recreation area, however some visitors may park at overlook to begin, with the trailhead 600’ to the right. As there are no painted lines, please be courteous of other visitors when parking your vehicle.
audioDescription: There are two entrances to this overlook on the east side of the road. The parking area is about 100’ long and does not have painted lines. There is a grassy area that extends 25’ out from the parking area. The wooden sign reads, “Smart View Overlook, Elevation 25 64." Approximately 5 feet past this sign is the path that leads to the Smart View Loop Trail. Beyond the path the land is less maintained; it is fairly level for 600 feet and then sharply drops. One sees low growing vegetation like bushes for several hundred feet before meeting the tree line. The slope of the hills converges at a low point creating a narrow sightline of the mountains beyond in the Pigg River Valley. The trees around the overlook are a mixture of dogwood, locust, maple, oak, cedar and pine. Most of the trees are between 20 to 30 feet tall. There are 4 trees in the grass island between the parkway and overlook parking.

quickFacts.value: Overlook along the Smart View Recreation Area that shows a view between two nearby converging hills into the Pigg River Valley below.
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Smart View Recreation Area
listingDescription: One of the original recreation areas developed for the Blue Ridge Parkway offering “a right smart view” of the surrounding area. Day use picnic area with nearby trail and historic home.

images.altText: A concrete picnic table sits empty on a grassy lawn dotted with colorful leaves
images.title: Enjoy a picnic under the shade trees
images.caption: Enjoy a picnic in one of the original 'recreation areas' on the Parkway

bodyText:
Smart View Recreation Area is one of the five original recreation sites developed for the parkway. Stanley Abbott, the parkway's original Landscape Architect, noted this area as “an attractive meadow land with views of the escarpment framed by low hills on either side.” Construction began in 1938 and the site opened to the public in the fall of 1940.

In addition to offering “a right smart view” of the Piedmont, the picnic area is noted today for its abundance of dogwood trees and other flowering plants which blossom in spring. Like many sites in the early years of the parkway, Smart View once housed a gas station and sandwich shop. Over time as the surrounding towns began to offer these amenities, the gas station and shop were closed.

The picnic site contains 72 individual sites with grills, including several accessible sites. There are 2 comfort stations and a pavilion. Picnic sites are on a first come first served basis. The area is typically open from late May to late October. This site offers access to the Smart View Trail—2.6 mile moderate trail which loops around the area.
audioDescription: The road to the picnic area is through the parking area for the Smart View Trail. Continue down the hill, past a pond on your left where the road turns and passes the Trails Cabin, a rough hewn log cabin with a cedar shake roof and stone chimney opening up to a view of the rolling mountains beyond. The picnic area itself is mostly wooded with concrete picnic tables and metal grills spaced throughout the loop. Some of the primary tree types include oak and hickory with a dogwood, azalea understory. The pavilion is approximately 42’ long and 24’ wide and is located along the first turn of the loop to the right. The first comfort station is across from this on the left side of the road and has a paved path leading to it. This area has a few paved paths leading to tables. As you exit the picnic loop a left left will cut back to the beginning of the loop, while a right will exit the loop and lead you out of the Smart View Picnic Area and back to the Parkway. To the right as you exit is a fenced field that sometimes contains cattle.

quickFacts.value: One of the original recreation areas developed for the Blue Ridge Parkway. Day use picnic area with nearby trail and historic home
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Tanbark Ridge Overlook
listingDescription: Don’t miss the view from this overlook just north of Asheville. Great for sunrises, stargazing, and fall leaf color. It’s a great place to get a taste of the Blue Ridge Parkway’s mountain scenery.

images.altText: Forested valley spans out across the foreground with layered mountains in the distance
images.title: View from Tanbark Ridge Overlook
images.caption: View from Tanbark Ridge Overlook

bodyText:
Enjoy an expansive view at this beautiful overlook located just north of Asheville.

Sunrise can be spectacular as this overlook faces east. Tanbark Ridge Overlook is a favorite with stargazers as well. In the small valley below, which is mostly forested, there is a little community aligned with Bull Creek Road. In the distance the mountains are High Swan, High Knob, and Lane Pinnacle. Behind the overlook, Tanbark Ridge ascends another 700 feet. Swan Mountain is behind Tanbark Ridge. 

The name tanbark comes from a leather tannery that is said to have been located on this ridge. Tanneries by their nature were foul smelling and usually located away from towns. A tannery situated on this ridge had the advantage of nearby resources—tannins from the bark of oak and hemlock trees and mountain breezes to blow away the smell of tannic acid and putrid animal hides.
audioDescription: This is a pull-through overlook parking area. It has a level asphalt parking surface with space for approximately a dozen cars. A grass median separates the parking area from the Parkway. There is one step up over a rock curb to a level sidewalk facing an expansive valley with mountains in the distance. The sidewalk is bounded on the front edge by a guardrail. A grassy area surrounds the sidewalk on one side, where visitors sometimes set up camp chairs or a picnic blanket to sit and enjoy the view.

title: Tanbark Ridge Tunnel
listingDescription: Take advantage of the unique opportunity to view and photograph one of the Blue Ridge Parkway’s iconic tunnels. The Tanbark Ridge Tunnel, set in a forested mountainside just a 15-minute drive north of Asheville, has gravel parking nearby making it an accessible location to enjoy the historic craftsmanship and beauty of this engineering feat.

images.altText: A wet road leads into a long tunnel with a decorative stone face surrounded by woods.
images.title: Tanbark Ridge Tunnel
images.caption: Tanbark Ridge Tunnel, one of 26 iconic Parkway tunnels

bodyText:
Located approximately fifteen miles north of Asheville, the Tanbark Ridge Tunnel allows visitors an opportunity to safely park their vehicle and view or photograph one of the Blue Ridge Parkway's iconic tunnels.

Limited gravel roadside parking is available on the south side of the tunnel. There is a slight drop-off from the asphalt roadway to the gravel--pull off the road slowly. Trails lead up to the historic Rattlesnake Lodge site (the relics of a summer home of a local Asheville physician that dates to the early 1900’s) and ultimately to the Mountains-to-Sea Trail.

The word "tanbark” in the name of this tunnel refers to tannins, organic compounds in the bark of oaks and hemlocks. Traditionally, the bark of these common mountain trees was bruised and broken to extract the tannins, which was used to tan hides for leather-making. The forest in this area is still predominantly mature oak and hemlock.

Although “social” trails appear to lead to the top of the tunnel, they are not Park Service authorized hiking trails and are steep, slippery, and dangerous. Traffic is busy on this section of the Parkway. Drivers from the south are approaching from a blind curve, drivers from the north are coming out of the tunnel. This makes anyone standing in the road very difficult to see. For your safety and the safety of others, please stay out of the road and do not walk inside the tunnel. Visitors are encouraged to enjoy the beauty and craftsmanship of the tunnel from the safety of the roadside.

Tunnels along the Parkway were created to reduce the impacts open blasting would have had on the mountainsides. After initial construction of the Parkway in 1935, tunnel building took place in the late 1940’s – 1950’s. A concrete lining was added to the interiors to prevent problems with groundwater dripping, freezing, and roadways icing inside the tunnels. The semi-circular arches on the entrances of the tunnels were added by Spanish and Italian stonemasons in the 1950’s and 60’s. The stone is all local, from less than 50 miles away from each build location.

There are 26 tunnels constructed along the entire 469 miles of the Blue Ridge Parkway. One is in the state of Virginia and 25 are in North Carolina. They range in length from 150 feet (Rough Ridge Tunnel) to 1,434 feet (Pine Mountain Tunnel).
audioDescription: Large dirt and gravel pull offs are on both sides of the Blue Ridge Parkway just south of the Tanbark Ridge Tunnel. These serve as a parking area to view the Tanbark Ridge Tunnel and nearby trail. The tunnel is nestled into the mountain ridge with trees surrounding it. A large rock outcropping is adjacent on one side. The handcrafted stonework on the face of the tunnel is similar in rock type as the native stone evident on the mountainside. Mid-elevation deciduous forest surrounds the area. To the west, the slope rises steadily up towards the top of the ridge. To the east, the slope drops steadily into the valley below.

title: The Loops Overlook
listingDescription: The Loops Overlook is a bucket list destination for railroad enthusiasts. Watch trains climb out of the valley below and up the engineering marvel known as “The Loops” as they struggle to cross the Blue Ridge Mountains at McKinney Gap. The Loops Overlook also provides views of the Historic Orchard at Altapass and the surrounding mountains.

images.altText: An exhibit panel sits in a grassy area with mountains in the background
images.title: Wayside at The Loops Overlook
images.caption: Wayside at The Loops Overlook

bodyText:
Railroad enthusiasts prize The Loops Overlook because it provides views of the trains ascending the Blue Ridge mountains from the valley below. The engineering marvel known as “The Loops” was constructed between 1905 and 1908 with the original intention of connecting the coalfields of Kentucky with the cotton mills of the Carolina Piedmont. It is 13.5 miles long, and contains 18 tunnels and many switchback curves -- giving “The Loops” its name. The trains are best viewed after the leaves fall from the trees.

The Overlook provides views to the north, northeast, east and southeast. To the north, lies McKinney Gap named for Charles McKinney (1780-1852) through which the North Toe River Valley can be viewed. To the east, lie Jackson Knob and the Peppers Creek Valley. To the southeast, lie the Linville Ridge, Dobson Knob and Bald Knob. 

Due to its eastward facing orientation, the Loops Overlook is an excellent place to watch the sunrise and is generally dark enough after nightfall to observe any astronomical phenomenon that occur in that portion of the sky.

The Loops is also a prime location to witness the natural phenomenon known as a fogfall.  When atmospheric conditions are right, fog forms in the North Toe River Valley, travels through McKinney Gap and because the fog is heavier than the surrounding air cascades down the slopes into the valley below.  This river of fog plunging through the gap and down the steep mountainside can rival the views of the parkway's most beautiful waterfalls.  The fogfall phenomenon occurs most frequently in the mornings from Mid-August to Early October. 

The Loops Overlook provides views of the Historic Orchard at Altapass lying directly below the overlook. The Historic Orchard at Altapass has been in operation for well over a century and was originally created by the Clinchfield Railroad in 1908.
audioDescription: The Loops Overlook is located directly above the Historic Orchard at Altapass at an elevation of 2980 ft. It provides views facing northeast, east and southeast. It is a small semicircular overlook with a grassy median and two wayside exhibits. There are no trees in the overlook, but is grassy and surrounded with by a mix of herbaceous plants and wildflowers. Directly below the Overlook lie rows of heirloom apple trees and the red barn/general store of the Historic Orchard at Altapass. Facing due east is Jackson Knob with the distinctive cut in the trees marking the route of the railway looping up the sides of the mountain. Dobson Knob and the Linville Ridge lie to the southeast. McKinney Gap and the Toe River Valley are northeast.

quickFacts.value: View of The Loops” engineering marvel railroad crossing the Blue Ridge Mountains. Scenic views of Peppers Creek, North Toe River Valley, and the Historic Orchard at Altapass
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Thunder Ridge Overlook
listingDescription: Thunder Ridge rises 2,600 feet above the Arnold Valley, offering sweeping views to the west. This favorite overlook is a wonderful quiet place to stop for a while, stretch your legs, and soak in some scenery. This is a great spot for photos and a picnic table offers seating for a mountain top meal when the weather cooperates.

images.altText: Fall colors cloak a vast swath of forest below, while mountains rise in the distance
images.title: View from Thunder Ridge Overlook
images.caption: View from Thunder Ridge Overlook

bodyText:
A favorite Parkway overlook, the Thunder Ridge Overlook provides a quiet perch towering over the Arnold Valley some 2,600 feet below.

The view includes parts of the Thunder Ridge and James River Face Wilderness areas and west to mountains 15 or more miles distant. The Appalachian Trail (AT) passes through the overlook on its way from Georgia to Maine, though a shorter alternative walk to the AT is the short 0.1 mile leg stretcher loop trail around a rocky outcrop. There is also a picnic table for a mountain top meal.

Note: Longer RVs/buses and vehicles pulling trailers should not use this overlook due to the inability to turnaround in the small parking lot with its single entry/exit point.
audioDescription: The Thunder Ridge Overlook is a balcony with low stone wall perched above an expansive view to the west over the Arnold Valley 2,600 feet below. Beyond the valley are ridges that stretch to the horizon miles away. The overlook is forested and the trees continue all the way to the valley floor where there is a mixture of farm lands, fence lines, and forest until the forested ridges begin.

quickFacts.value: This is one of many overlooks along the Appalachian National Scenic Trail from Georgia to Maine. The Thunder Ridge Overlook sits just outside the boundary of the Thunder Ridge Wilderness area and offers the chance to ponder the value of wild places and Wilderness in today’s society.
quickFacts.name: Significance

quickFacts.value: Part of the Appalachian National Scenic Trail and on the boundary of the Thunder Ridge Wilderness area.
quickFacts.name: Designation

title: Trail Cabin at Smart View Recreation Area
listingDescription: An example of an early cabin built by settlers in this region. The cabin looks out into the piedmont region below. Nearby is the Smart View Picnic Area and trail.

images.altText: A 12 by 12 log cabin with gaps between the boards and a stone chimney sits atop a hill.
images.title: Trail Family Cabin
images.caption: Typical of the early style Appalachian cabin, the Trail Family Cabin can be seen up at Smart View.

bodyText:
Pioneer families began to settle in present day Floyd County in the 1740s and in Franklin County around the time of the American Revolution. Many made their homes in the mountains along the present-day Blue Ridge Parkway, including the family of W.J. Trail whose cabin today looks out onto the rolling hills of the Piedmont.

This one-room cabin style was common in the area. Oftentimes the initial home was a simple structure—people needed a decent shelter fast so that they could move on to other activities that sustained their livelihood. Over time, as families grew and became more established on the land, extensions would be added to the house or a new home might be constructed nearby. Once this cabin no longer served as a home, it was used as a barn.

During the development of the parkway, the cabin, like many other structures found along the way, was left to gradually fade back into the landscape and by 1947, little remained of the original structure. 

Today, the cabin is closed to visitors, but it is possible to look between the logs and see what remains; pieces of a floor and the fireplace but not much else. The cabin today lacks chinking—a mixture of clay, sand, lime, silt, ash, and dirt, that would have been placed between the logs. This protective mixture would have sealed the structure, providing some temperature control and keeping water from pooling between the logs. In another effort to seal the cabin, windows were kept small; before glass, they would be covered with animal skin or greased paper.

The 2.6-mile easy to moderate Smart View Loop Trail passes here. There is also a bench near the cabin making it an ideal place to stop and take in the view or visit the adjacent picnic area.
audioDescription: From the parking area the land slopes downward, about 25’ out from the parking area there is a split rail fence that goes in front and down the left side of the land around the cabin. The cabin stands 50’ away from the front portion of the fence. By the parking area there is a wayside about the cabin that reads: “Trail Cabin. Once common among the Blue Ridge, there remains but a few of the rough log buildings such as this cabin. While built in the 1890s by the Trail family, it is typical of the first cabins built by pioneers throughout the forested sections of our country. United States Department of the Interior, National Park Service.” The cabin itself is about 15 by 15feet. It is built on a hill so one side is built up slightly more to make the home level. At its tallest point, the cabin is about 12’ high. There is a rock chimney on one side. Since there is a lack of chinking between the stacked logs there is 3” - 6” of space between rows of logs depending on size and one can see clear into the structure. The door is on the left side of the building but is closed. Inside there are serval large logs running lengthwise across the floor, but the remainder is dirt. The only other visible trace is the stone fireplace, situated perpendicular to the logs. Past the cabin, about 18’ ahead is a bench that looks out into the land below, short shrubs rolling down a steep slope with mountains rolling on into the distance. To the left and right of this clearing are woods.

quickFacts.value: Near the Smart View Picnic Area
quickFacts.name: Location

title: View Black Mountain Overlook
listingDescription: This scenic overlook on the Blue Ridge Parkway offers views of the Black Mountains as they tower over the surrounding South Toe River valley below. The Black Mountains are the tallest range in the Eastern United States, containing eighteen peaks over 6300 feet above sea level. The breadth of the valley below helps showcase the view of this range. With its western facing aspect and limited light pollution sunsets and stargazing are possible.

images.altText: Lush, forested mountains stand uninterrupted beneath a blue sky
images.title: View from Black Mountain overlook
images.caption: View Black Mountain Overlook

bodyText:
Black Mountain Overlook provides a view of the entire Black Mountain Range, which is the tallest range east of the Black Hills in South Dakota. Six of the ten highest peaks in the eastern United States are in the Black Mountain range, as well as 18 peaks over 6,300 feet in elevation. The shadows of these mountains, cast long over the valleys below, might be one reason for the name. The dark and dense spruce fir forest cloaking the ridge tops may be another.

The Black Mountains are home to Mount Mitchell, the tallest peak east of the Mississippi River (6,684 feet). A side trip Mount Mitchell State Park provides visitors with an opportunity to walk to the top of the mountain. This impressive mountain range rises out of the valley created by the South Toe River as it flows northward. Big Ridge and Seven Mile Ridge dwarf in comparison yet add reference and breadth to the valley below. 

With its western facing view, this overlook is an excellent spot for viewing sunsets over the lofty peaks of the Black Mountains.
audioDescription: This overlook is a long and narrow roadway pullout with a narrow parking area and a grassy median. To the west the entire range of the Black Mountains, which is the tallest range in the Eastern United States can be seen, including Mount Mitchell, the tallest peak east of the Black Hills in South Dakota. To the southwest, the Black Mountain Gap separates the Blue Ridge Mountains and the Black Mountains. The South Toe River headwaters begin from this point on their serpentine path northward through the valley. The grass on the edge of the overlook changes to a mixed deciduous forest at the ends. A mix of wildflowers and midlevel ground cover border the front of the overlook, providing a natural barrier from the steep down sloping hillside.

quickFacts.value: Views of the Black Mountains, the tallest range in the eastern United States
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Waterrock Knob Viewpoint and Trail
listingDescription: Escape the crowds and experience the Parkway’s highest peak at Waterrock Knob. Unparalleled views, a hike to the summit, a visitor center, and picnic tables make this a great spot to spend your time.

images.altText: Wooden sign reading Waterrock Knob Trail with rolling mountains in distance
images.title: Waterrock Knob Parking & Trailhead
images.caption: Take in the views and take a (short) hike!

bodyText:
Waterrock Knob is truly a hidden gem on the Blue Ridge Parkway. Located just 18 miles from the southern end of the Parkway and farther away from larger cities, it has a more remote and quiet feel to it. Perfect for escaping the crowds you sometimes find at other park locations!

Waterrock Knob has the highest elevation on the Parkway. The visitor center is located at 5,820 feet and the summit itself is 6,273 feet. A large open parking area can provide fantastic long-distance views anytime, but can be particularly stunning for sunrise and sunset. Fog and clouds are common here and temperatures are much cooler than in the surrounding valleys. High elevation deciduous trees mix with the spruce/fir forest to create this mountain retreat. Night owls also enjoy Waterrock Knob’s dark skies for star gazing. A visitor center, picnic tables, seasonal restrooms and a hike to the summit make this a hard to beat destination!

The trail to the summit and back is round trip a mile but the elevation gain is 460 feet so take your time and enjoy the walk. The first .2 miles are paved, leading to an uneven and, at times steep, dirt and rock path.
audioDescription: The large, paved parking lot at Waterrock Knob stands at 58 20 feet with the summit itself rising in front of you at 62 37 feet, covered in the evergreen of a spruce and fir forest. To the right is a wooden sign reading "Waterrock Knob Trail Waterrock Knob point 5 miles Pedestrian Overlook point 2 miles." Beyond the sign the mountains fade off into the distance in waves and the road can be seen like a ribbon halfway up one of the mountains. The sign stands in grass and is just beyond a sidewalk. The paved sidewalk leads off to the left, starting its climb to the summit and stays paved until one reaches the overlook. There are stone steps with a wooden handrail along this trail. It is approximately 2 feet wide. In the spring flowers line some of the trail, along with leafless trees interspersed with tall evergreens. The views from the overlook are similar to those from the parking lot and often one sees a blanket of white fog with islands of rounded topped mountains popping up above the fog for tens of miles. Turning further to the right is the road leaving the lot and even further another stretch of tree covered mountains on the other side of the parking lot. There are two small concrete block restroom buildings on this end of the parking lot. Across the paved roadway of the parking lot stands a one story visitor center adjacent to the mountain. Fog and clouds are common here, making the air colder than that off the mountain. On a clear day the views seem never-ending with mountain ranges beyond mountain ranges, changing color with distance from the greens of summer or the red orange of fall to the blue of distance.

title: Wilson Creek Valley Overlook
listingDescription: Scenic overlook with far-ranging views of the mountains. On a clear day, downtown Charlotte and Kings Mountain are visible on the horizon. Good photography spot.

images.altText: Blue tinted mountains stretch to the horizon under a pale winter sky
images.title: Wilson Creek Valley Overlook
images.caption: Mountains stretch to the horizon at Wilson Creek Valley Overlook

bodyText: This overlook provides a scenic view to the south toward South Mountain State Park and the South Carolina border. On a clear day, downtown Charlotte and Kings Mountain are visible on the horizon. To the west MacRae’s Peak offers more photo opportunities.
audioDescription: Long, two-lane wide parking area with asphalt sidewalk and stone curbs. A narrow stone curb separates the parking area from the Parkway. The left half of the overlook has a view of mountains to the south and southeast down to the South Carolina border. The right half has a grassy strip with boulders and trees. Also, to the left is a view of a high, rounded granite peak (MacRae’s). trees are on the other three sides.

title: Yankee Horse Ridge Overlook
listingDescription: Yankee Horse Ridge is a favorite overlook with many activities from one location. Hike the 0.1 miles to see the waterfall or wander the old logging railroad in search of spring wildflowers, wildlife, and solitude. Enjoy a picnic meal in the cool shade of the Appalachian forest regrowth to get a nice break from driving.

images.altText: Water cascades over a rock outcropping in a lush, green forest
images.title: Wigwam Falls at Yankee Horse Ridge
images.caption: Wigwam Falls at Yankee Horse Ridge

bodyText:
Yankee Horse Ridge Overlook is known for two popular attractions: Wigwam Falls and the Irish Creek Railroad. This overlook is a family favorite for easy leg stretcher trails, picnic meals, and the relaxing sounds of the small stream flowing through the site. It is also a great place to search for wildflowers and migrating birds each spring.

Wigwam Falls is one of the easiest to access waterfalls between Waynesboro and Roanoke, VA. It is a 0.1 mile walk to its base along a gently flowing stream. This waterfall is greatly impacted by rainfall – becoming more active and impressive following a recent storm.

The Irish Creek Railroad was a 42 inch narrow gauge railway used by the South River Lumber Company based in nearby Cornwall, VA. Operated from 1916 to 1939, Climax locomotives climbed the mountain slopes to access and remove timber. Temporary track lines were constructed off branching off of the main trunk to provide access for loggers into various hollows. The felled trees would be loaded onto log cars to be pulled back to the sawmill. A small section of track and an old trestle have been reconstructed near the overlook, and visitors are welcome to stroll south along the old line for about half a mile to explore the re-growing forest. This exhibit commemorates timber-mining operations of the 19th century including the valuable lessons society learned from its affects.
audioDescription: The Yankee Horse Ridge Overlook has a flat parking area with room for about 8 vehicles. A stone staircase leads up to the middle of a restored section of track about stretching about 200 feet north and south. To the right of the steps, the tracks run across a restored wooden tresstle that spans a small, rocky creek. Wigwam Falls is upstream a few hundred feet above this trestle. On the northern end of the restored tracks, is another stone staircase that leads to a single stone picnic table surrounded by forest.

quickFacts.value: The restored section of the old Irish Creek Railroad serves as a reminder of the timbering operations which affected large parts of the Blue Ridge in the early decades of this century.

quickFacts.value: Nominated for National Register of Historic Places
